bibl.title: [Letter] 1838 Jun. 15 [to] H.D. Jameson / Henry King
bibl.author: King, Henry
bibl.note: This is a letter dated June 15, 1838 from Henry King to his uncle H.D. Jameson. In the letter King writes to his mother, and expresses his well-being as part of his battalion.

projectDesc.p: Created for the University of Tennessee Digital Library

editorialDecl.p: Quotation marks retained as data except inside q tags
Errors in transcription of the printed text controlled with X-Metal 3.0 spell-checker; text has also been thoroughly proofread.
Corrections and normalization represented by editorial tags.
Catchwords and directional notes such as "turn page over" have been omitted.

refsDecl.p: ID attributes provided for only those pages, chapters, or illustrations toward which a reference or figure points.

div1.p: I wish to write a few lines to Mother.

Dear Mother I received yours and Cousin Sarah Moors letters I the seventh of June I was truly glad to hear that the family was all well. But I was verry sorry to hear that ant Sally Gannaway was sick I have heard from by Cousin Williams letter that she is better which I was much pleased We are stil at Rosses landing and expect to remain hear the balance of our time. Cousin William Albert and myself are all in amess to gether and we far verry well the our mess mates are all verry friendly they are principly from the neighbour hood I have feared that all of thoes things which you informed me to be tru there are a great many ceanless boys in our battalion some of them have lost a part of their clothing Cousin William Albert and Myself have not los lost the firs thing. our clothing I expect is sufficient to stand us There are some sickly boys in the battalion ther is only me in Cap john A Macklins company Tel Mr snell that Brite Snell is fat as a bare her Cousin William Albert and myself hav had our helth safir give my love and respect to all of my friends and relations
